This is an improved version of my previous offering, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:369475. The improvement is a simpler script from the point of view of the user. Only phone dimensions need be defined and all the rest is calculated. As a bonus I also cut out unneeded material saving both material and printing time.
To create the STL file you need to customize the Python script and execute it within FreeCAD. Customizing is simply measuring the dimension of your phone (with protective case where used) and editing the Python script. You also need to state the pathname of the STL that is created.
FreeCAD is an Open Source modelling toolset available for all popular platforms, Windows, Linux and Mac. Get it from http://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/index.php?title=Getting_started.

Three steps to making a stable platform while using minimal amount of material.

Faced with numerous request for phone docks of different sizes I decided that the most efficient use of my time was to write a script in Python where the basic phone dimensions were set as variables and all other dimensions and modelling carried out by software.
FreeCAD provides the perfect environment for doing this.
Step 1. Create a box a bit wider than the phone, deep enough for the phone to lean backwards without toppling over and high enough to be in proportion to the phone when slotted in.
Step 2. Cut a slot in the box for inserting the phone. It needs to be at least as wide as the phone and its depth at least as much as the phones depth.
Step 3. Remove all unneeded material while leaving a stable structure that won't topple over.

remixed_from.author: luisglez
remixed_from.title: Soporte para brocha de afeitar - Shaving brush holder

description.text:
One of the first things I printed after calibrating was the shave brush by luisglez. It didn't print well because my bed shifted mid print so I never posted it as a make, but it still was perfectly capable of holding up a brush. In fact, to this day I still am using my sad layer shifted brush stand.

It was perfect at holding my brush handle. The problem is that it held it too close to the base, so smooshed the brush bristles down. To avoid this I hang it at the end of the brush where the bristles come out, giving it an extra bit of space.

This is that model, but lengthened in the back, and with a few other tweaks. The original model has some strange shifting of parts, so I did some trimming and filling to try to make it a little smoother. It wasn't a problem before, and the defects didn't really print, but now they are even less likely to do so. I also added a support to the one internal overhang, so if you can print the curves (with or without supports from the build plate) the rest of it should print correctly.

Printer:

Folger Tech Kossel Rev B

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

Any

Notes:

If your printer does overhangs well, you should be able to print this without any supports. If it's not so great with overhangs you may want to use some supports from the build plate. The rest of it should print without supports on the model unless your printer is catastrophically bad at overhangs.

Higher resolution is prettier in the curves, but there isn't anything so delicate that you can't print it at a much larger layer height. Any infill should be sufficient, so long as your printer can create the top layers cleanly enough afterward. I'll probably do 30%, but it's also only going to be a couple layers of infill anyway.

I would print this on the back, with the base and the top jutting into the sky for easy printing.

For stronger printing you should print it on one of the sides with the top side and bottom on the plate, but then you will probably need supports and be very confident of your printer's ability to print overhangs. Or even more strongly printed on it's side with just the edge of the bottom on the bed and the rest of the base, back, and top resting on supports. If you need the stand to be that strong, maybe you need a lighter shaving brush rather than going though all that effort.

Windows 10 3D Builder

I used the 3D Builder program that comes with Windows 10 to modify this model.

I sliced the bottom and the top from the back, moved the top away from the bottom enough to suit my needs, then stretched the back so that it was long enough to connect to the top without maintaining aspect ratio. Then merged them all back together.

After that I used cubes to patch up some of the faces to make them a little less erratic; in some cases filling in a gap, in others trimming it down. Not anything more than .1mm or so, and really nothing I needed to worry about, except I wanted to see what I could do with the software.

Finally I added a pyramid, squished it almost flat, clipped off the tip so it didn't poke though the back, then merged it in to create a small strip of support that will not look bad left on the final model (in my humble opinion).
Please share your prints! Will love to see how yours turn out!

print_settings.Notes:: I used supports with this print so I recommend them. I used a .2 layer height for a quick print. and about 20% infill.

title: Wanhao i3 V2 Extruder fan adapter for 50mm blower fan

description.text:
Edit: 5/30/17: I had a comment recently from TeamTEOR saying that he had done some tests regarding the 40mm stock fan Vs this adapter. According to his tests the adapter did improve the cooling on his printer. I still don't have any of the tools needed to measure any differences myself, so I just have to take his word for it.
Edit: 2/23/17: So a short while ago I changed over to another variation on this adapter. So I wanted to show off what was left of the dust stuck onto the print from 4 months of use. Now all the lose dust is gone by now so all you can see is the stuck on dust. I used my phones camera to take some pictures so they are not of the best quality. To me this is a way to prove through image that the adapter can successfully move air as the dust was pushed through the adapter by the fan. Another thing I showed was that I recently grabbed some m4 screws that were 20mm long. The normal screws were just long enough to work and the countersunk ones were just a bit too short.

Edit: 1/30/17: Well the fans game, not bearing the same label as the pictures. They also don't seem that great to be honest. Its been around 3 to 4 months since I started using a blower fan and the printer is doing great. Several alternative designs have also appeared meaning the use of squirrel fans is becoming more common.

Edit 1/9/17: I found a fan bearing the same label as the one I have been using for this adapter on ebay. I order one to see if it is similar to the one I have. I will update when I get the fan.

This is a simple one part adapter, for a 50 mm blower fan. This allows you to swap the standard 40mm axial fan with a 50mm blower fan. I started this around late October of 2016 and started using it early November. I have been using my printer for about 3 weeks with this mod and no real noticeable change from the 40mm fan.

I have included two models currently, one has integrated spacers and the other does not. This print uses the two stock screws that held the 40mm fan on the printer. The print forces fan orientation as seen above in the pictures. I recommend grabbing a fan that can provide a lot of push. The fan I use sadly only has 12 volts listed and no amps listed ( as seen in the pictures) I ordered a 15 amp for testing, however I got stuck with a bad fan. It MAY be enough flow, however I could not do proper print tests with it.

I recommend watching were you get a fan from as you could not get what you expected. Even happen to me while trying to find a fan to link for this adapter. As for screws I just used some #8 UNC-32x1" screws I had lying around.

Seems to work fine as a replacement and works with the stock cooling fan and the dii cooler. I provided pictures above of both cooling fans mounted. These are the only cooling fans I tried.

Printer:

Wanhao duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used supports with this print so I recommend them. I used a .2 layer height for a quick print. and about 20% infill.

Why This design

I designed this adapter based on what I learned from my previous experiences with the 2 in 1 cooler concept. I was using the AzzA brace at the time of designing this and placed the part within the movement area. While it does have to curve the air I think enough air is moved by the blower fan.

comments.text: THANKS!!! I was so done and tired of heat creep, this has totally solved that for me. With the 40mm fan my heatsink was in the 50-60c range and I was dealing a lot with my PLA getting stuck. Even after a 7 hour print with PETG running at 250c the heatsink was only a max of 45c (and my printer is inside of a cabinet). I am pretty sure the heatsink will be cooler with PLA running at 220. I added a little silver thermal paste to the bottom of the heatsink where it touches the cooling block to help with heat transfer. Making this with the extensions to get rid of the white tubes was a fantastic idea! I printed in PLA, but will reprint it in PETG now that I can.
comments.author: TeamTEOR

comments.text: Glad to hear it worked out for you, I never had any temperature measuring tools on hand. Because of that I was never able to determine if any difference in temperature was actually made. I learned something new today, thanks.

With the control board fan on it read around 50dB. With the control and extruder fan on it read 55dB. With all the fans on running a diii cooler as part cooler I got 56dB. With all fans running and the stock 30mm part cooler it read 57dB.  Hope this helps.

title: RETRO mini-bob
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This retro-styled mini-bob is a simple design but it offers a lot of fun! Unfortunately I couldn't make a video up to now but here are two videos of the original bob:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EU2a39ZfssQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uN_MRTIMHz4

Choose your team, print and assemble your mini-bob, build your own bobsled run and take the challenge: http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/bobsleigh-challenge

ASSEMBLING:
You also find a litte construction manual in the main-picture of the mini-bob. Beside the printed parts you need the following materials: glue, 8 screws (20 mm long; 3 x 16) and some weights (sinkers for fishing work great, or something else that's heavy).

For the assembling take the following steps and compare the pictures:

  1. Combine the seal and the top-part. (use glue)
  2. Fill up the bottom-parts empty segments with something heavy like lead (for example sinkers for fishing).
  3. Combine the bottom- and the top-part
  4. Attach the eight screws (3 x 16) to the bob
  5. Attach your flag to the flag-base (use glue)
  6. Attach the flag to the bob (use glue)
  7. Attach the visors to the pilots heads
  8. Attach the pilots to the bob (use glue)
  9. Attach the cockpit to the bob (use glue)
  10. Use sand-paper to make the surface of the bottom-part smooth. After the sandpaper you can use an old jeans: rob it over the cloth until the bottom surface gets shiny. That minimises the friction and your mini-bob gets faster.

Check out NC Hippy's funny assembling video: https://youtu.be/31XsKs21dOs
and a great assembling video from Abernus69: https://youtu.be/MwNwSC1L2_M
Big thx for making those :-)

Team flags:
There is also a top-part available in the files with no flag. If you want to choose a flag, print the normal top-part and the flag-base as well. Then choose one of the following team flags:

  • America: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1939523
  • Canada: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1939525
  • China: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2058847
  • Fortress: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2461004

  • The dark side: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1949025

If a specific flag is missing and you want me to create one, or if you designed a new one and want me to link it in the description, just write a comment or a message.

TIP: Using an empty bottle makes the building of the bobsled run verry easy :-)

Help creating new designs for the pilots (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1945717) or the bob and let me know if you want me to add them here.

Have fun and remember....don't eat yellow snow

comments.text: The printtime depends on different factors like the infill you use and the layer-hight. With my ultimaker, 4mm layer-hight and 50% infill it took about 24 hours for all parts. Depending on what slicer-software you're using, the Information about the duration of the print should be available. Also the down-scaling should be possible with you're slicer software. if not you can use tinkercad for example to do the downscaling. I used Cura as slicer-software which supports both (estimated printtime and downscaling). I used about 300 grams of lead. When you downscale the model, you have to find smaller screws that will fit or find an other solution to Combine the parts (for example glue) but it should be possible. Just havent tried it yet.

title: Flashlight Mount for Evolve Carbon GT

description.text:
Flashlight mount for Evolve Carbon GT (should fit Bamboo GT and possibly any longboard that uses Gullwing Trucks). Fits flashlight diameter less than 26mm angled at 7 degrees.

This was specifically designed for the DQG 4th Tiny and is mounted via foam pressure fit.

comments.text: Awesome design!
comments.author: krunkosaurus

comments.text:
From what I observed of the Olight S1, the magnet holder would require the mount to pretty much encompass the entire flashlight. This would make the mount pretty bulky. If you cut the tube shorter, you would definitely have rattling issues, since the mid section of the flashlight is thinner in circumference than the front and end caps. You could try wrapping the mid tube in something rubbery and have it kind of like a press fit to give it extra support along with the magnet, but not sure how long that'll last.
The magnet itself, I would just glue it on. What do you think?
comments.author: krunkosaurus

comments.text: I thought about and agreed about much of what you said. Especially the issue with the tail cap being slighty thicker than the body. I'm currently thinking to just put velcro tape on the bottom of the board and sliding the flashlight clip through that. If the velcro was thick enough it could reduce shakiness. Im the meantime I just bought read and front Thunderbolt lights from evolve.com. The rear lights are exceptionally bright but the front ones are only 80 lumens for 1.5 hours or so.

Basically gutted out and fitted the other part inside.
To keep everything together, I used a ball point pen spring, cut in half, and a 4 mm or 5/32 ball bearing.
Insert the spring into the hole, put the bearing on top, force down with your finger and insert the piece into the other part.
The bearing will sort of lock into the depression holes I have put inside.
It will hold closed and when you apply the opening force, don't rip the guts out of it, gently pull it up and you will hear and feel the bearing snap into the open position.
With a little work it could have a flash from a phone camera inserted and the thing would Flash like the Movie.

remixed_from.author: onasiis
remixed_from.title: Drag Knife - Cuchilla de corte para CNC (papel, vinilo, etc.)

title: Drag Knife for MPCNC universal mount

description.text:
Update 2016-12-03: increased space for universam mount.

I've remixed the original drag knife from onasiis, adapting for the universal mount of the MPCNC.

You will need:

  • 2x 608Z bearings
  • 2x M3 scews for the blade holder
  • 4x M4 screws and nuts for the 2 part of the body

The round shaft should fit the inside of the bearings tight. You need to sand the shaft until you are able to insert the shaft in the bearings. You will need to apply a force to insert the shaft in the bearings, do not sand the shaft too much, otherwise the part that holds the blade will fall out from the bearings.

The M3 screws do not need nuts, they will fit the hole in the rotor part. I've also increased the space between the two holes, thus you can leave tighten the left screw and untighten only the right screw when you need to remove the blade.

Please note that the uploaded file are slightly different from the printed one in the pictures. I've made little improvements, but I didn't print them again. If you find something wrong, let me know.

I plan to design a blade cover in order to be on the safe side when I have time.

This is a simple cube I use to calibrate my extruder when I use repetier host. Coms in great when you have to calculate your extrusion multiplier. great little tool

Print this at a slie of .3  and then using a caliper measure the thickness of your walls should mach your wall thick that you chose in your setup. If not divide the wanted wall thickness by you resulted wall thickness. and get the proper extrusion multiplier setting should help you get a cleaner print I know it helped me.

I'm not really keen on the flip cases for mobile phones because I can never hold them with the cover folded right back. Also, the S7 Edge one has a swipe hole... and a point that pocket contents such as car keys can get in and scratch the screen... which is curved, so there is no effective tempered glass full-screen protector.

This is a solid case for a Samsung S7 Edge. It has magnetic locks (you'll need 3mm diameter by 2mm thick, N42 is good), and it doesn't have a window for swiping your finger or your car keys to gouge the screen through. You can put the lid in your pocket while you're using the screen.

The first layer has the Voronoi cut out and as it's printed on glass it's smooth so the next layer contrasts really well. The one in the images was printed in metallic gold nGen from ColorFabb.

It's really quite light weight (with a hexagonal internal structure to remove plastic) and doesn't add a great deal of bulk (about 3mm)

WARNING
If you do print this on glass, the case is REALLY smooth and I can confirm that this case has protected my phone from 2 falls out of my pocket as I've gotten into my car, and one trip and throw. Obviously, I cannot rate it for your accidents :)

VERSION 2 now available (silver in the photos)
Well, ok, it's labeled v4. I found that in the dropping I lost a few magnetic corners, and the case split a little between the power and volume button, so I beefed it up a bit. As a consequence, I have not dropped it once yet - possibly due to the inner curve and squarer edges. This design is not for everyone, but it works better than the original for me.

Also I rounded off some of the holes, and made a recess for a large heaphone plug.

fits just fine ... no rescaling!
(if tension gets low over time you may use the two little holes to apply a cable tie)

Watch here: https://youtu.be/agKe5erwogQ

That's right, my wife wasn't satisfied with just painting all the models. Now she's making the models too? She's not going to need me at all pretty soon...

So recently we got ZBrush Core, which if you haven't heard of it, it's definitely worth checking out. It's a fully fledged 3D sculpting program and people have created amazingly detail models in ZBrush. So she thought she'd just mess around with the program, and her first time opening up the program, she created this cute little penguin. I'm jealous and impressed by her skills.

So I printed it out for her (settings below) and she painted it up. She used some primer then used an airbrush to paint the whole thing black. After that she took a paintbrush to add in the white for the body and the rest of the facial details.

description.text:
23.05.2017: Added English version of the user manual. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2339991. Welcome!
UPDATE: I did it! TR8 on the transmission increased speed to 9000мм\min!!! Watch the video http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2154208
UPDATE: Added spindle mount and cable holder
UPDATE: Added user manual!!!
UPDATE:Added drawings of parts from plywood.

To create your own desktop CNC router I decided after saw the work liquidhandwash. Just to repeat did not want, so I decided to improve it for yourself.
What was taken as a basis:
-case design
-view electronics
-mounting parts guide

What has been redone
-Changed the dimensions of the housing to increase the amount of processing. Now he is 360х240х40 mm. Also added holes in the handle to conveniently move the machine to another place.
instead of the acrylic housing parts made of 10mm plywood. Plywood is stronger and more available material than acrylic in my opinion.
The bronze nuts were replaced with nylon because annoying squeak when rotating. Also the longer the nuts are allowed to refuse compensating nuts, which facilitated the rotation of the screw
-instead of a DC motor was used Dremel 395 power 125W with a speed of 10000-40000. Because of this increased accuracy of processing of details.
-completely redesigned the electronics housing. Now it is fully printed on a 3D printer. It has all the connectors.
-added control panel on the front panel of the machine on which the e-stop button, pause and start of the work, as well as connector z-probe. thanks Jack it is easy to put the engraving on uneven surfaces.
-added a sacrificial table on the desktop of hardboard, allowing you to cut through the plywood without damaging the Desk of the machine.

It is also planned to add a laser engraving of materials, thereby to obtain a more versatile tool in my workshop.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

40%

Remix of airald's excellent autoclose hinge.

I have changed a couple of things to suit my needs.

  1. The autoclose angle has been halved. Mainly to reduce the height rise of the door.
  2. I have added an option for a pan-head bolt (M4)
  3. I have added a back plate to reduce the stress on the acrylic door I plan to use.
  4. I have added left and right handed versions. The left hand version is designed to mount on the left side of a door (with it opening towards you).

title: Case for Mini Thermal Receipt Printer and ESP8266

description.text:
This is a Thermal Printer Case. It is a Remix of "Desk Thermal Printer Case" made in openSCAD so it is configurable. It is much sturdier (5mm thick wales) than the original and uses only two parts. NO support is needed. Use four rubber feet on the bottom side. Add/remove hole from the front panel if needed for your project.

The goal of this project was to connect my printer as an IoT device with its own homepage so I didn't need Android drivers or programs to print text on it! A demo of this is included as 'ESP_ThermalPrinter_webbpage_V4.ino' (it is a simple webb-page that lets the user create a printed checklist).

The same Arduino program is capable of receiving and printing rows of byts form the Javascript 'bit.html' eg. for real-time printing of measurements. This is a slow process!

The (demo) program 'ESP_ThermalPrinter_MQTT_V1.ino' turns the printer in to a MQTT node and prints the incoming values.

UPDATES:
6 dec 2016
SP_ThermalPrinter_webbpage_V4.ino Now saves and loads list to/from browser storage.
SP_ThermalPrinter_webbpage_V4.ino Handles the LED:s.
SP_ThermalPrinter_webbpage_V4.ino The printout have a header and a footer.
SP_ThermalPrinter_webbpage_V4.ino Minor layout changes in home page.
New photos added.

Printer:

WT150

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you print TPCbox.stl with the opening facing down NO support is needed!!!

Tips!

Depending on your printer and its tolerances it might be a good idea to clean the smaller holes whit a drill.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Cold end blower conversion

description.text:
Blower fan conversion for cold end.

Uses a 50x50x15mm blower fan.

You will need one longer m3 screw than the original (~55mm) , and one shorter.
Don't know exactly how long, I just cut them until they fit.

comments.text: Would this benefit from directing the air exiting the heat sink upward? so coolish air doesn't hit the print, important if your printing ABS
comments.author: Maddog2050

comments.text: Well I was thinking about doing that but there isn't really enough room. This thing has bad airflow as it is and I think putting a shroud on the other side of the heatsink would make it even worse.
comments.author: Maddog2050

comments.text: Do you have the source files available? This doesn't seem to fit on my version (Maker Select V2.1) because the original part cooling fan mount is too high up to fit in the slot cut out for it.
comments.author: Thiney49

comments.text: Yeah I can imagine that part differs a bit between printers. It would probably be best to cut it off and remove the cavity in the fan shroud, that would probably give the best airflow. Added a step file for you.
comments.author: Thiney49

comments.text: I need to print this one just to print it. Pretty cool that someone else also thought about using a blower fan in place of the 40mm stock extruder fan.
comments.author: FilamentCorner

comments.text: Yeah I was sure I had seen something similar before but I couldn't find it at the time, so I made my own.
comments.author: FilamentCorner

comments.text: Trying to find the best way to do a print. Currently trying it with supports, hoping it comes out well.
comments.author: jsege

comments.text: Oh, I added manual supports in Simplify3d where they could be removed. Can possibly be done without manual support if you set infill density very low so you can get it out of the high part in the back.
comments.author: FilamentCorner

comments.text: I finally managed to print one with supports. I found out my printer needed some maintenance when one of the z lead screw nuts came loose from the x axis. I think the screws holding it together just came loose from usage over time. I will take some part pictures when I get a chance.
comments.author: jsege

comments.text: notice any improvement?
comments.author: AGreenV5

comments.text: In terms of noise and not sticking your hex key in the fan, yes. Other than that I have no way of measuring the temperature, but at least it seams sufficient. I have printed about 40 hours with this and have not noticed anything better or worse. Although my blower fan is pretty weak, this could use one of those stronger fans, 0.3A or so.

Here is a YouTube Play list relating to this
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUqt0sTiXUDe-o4b8O-j9MhNI2uV1qTq1

Low-voltage differential signaling, or LVDS, also known as TIA/EIA-644,.

LVDS is a differential signaling system, meaning that it transmits information as the difference between the voltages on a pair of wires; the two wire voltages are compared at the receiver. In a typical implementation, the transmitter injects a constant current of 3.5 mA into the wires, with the direction of current determining the digital logic level. The current passes through a termination resistor of about 100 to 120 ohms (matched to the cable's characteristic impedance to reduce reflections) at the receiving end, and then returns in the opposite direction via the other wire. From Ohm's law, the voltage difference across the resistor is therefore about 350 mV. The receiver senses the polarity of this voltage to determine the logic level.

As long as there is tight electric- and magnetic-field coupling between the two wires, LVDS reduces the generation of electromagnetic noise. This noise reduction is due to the equal and opposite current flow in the two wires creating equal and opposite electromagnetic fields that tend to cancel each other. In addition, the tightly coupled transmission wires will reduce susceptibility to electromagnetic noise interference because the noise will equally affect each wire and appear as a common-mode noise. The LVDS receiver is unaffected by common mode noise because it senses the differential voltage, which is not affected by common mode voltage changes.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-voltage_differential_signaling

title: USS Voyager Shuttle Type 9
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hallo!
Ich habe versucht das Shuttle Type 9 der U.S.S. Voyager für den 3D Druck zu erstellen. Im Entwurfmodus habe ich die Abmessungen : Länge: 25 cm; Höhe: 6,4 cm; Breite 6,58 cm ; gewählt. Einige der Details sind aber in einer sehr kleinen Abmessung und könnten in diesem Format von meinem Drucker nicht erstellt werden. Wenn man also mehr Details möchte, so sollte man ein grösserers Format einstellen. Allerdings müssten dann die einzelnen Bauteile eventuell nochmals in weitere Segmmente aufgeteilt werden.

Auf alle Fälle wünsche ich viel Spass damit.

Das Modell habe ich mit Sketchup 2017(Freeware) entworfen. Entsprechende Dateien sind dabei.

Hello!
I have tried Shuttle Type 9 of U.S.S. Voyager for 3D printing. In design mode I have the dimensions: Length: 25 cm; Height: 6.4 cm; Width 6,58 cm; Selected. Some of the details are in a very small size and could not be created in this format by my printer. So if you want more details, you should set a larger format. However, the individual components might have to be divided into further segments.

In any case, I wish you much fun with it.

I designed the model with Sketchup 2017 (Freeware). Corresponding files are included.

I did use support for one of the cuts but if you printer has a good cooling it might not even be necessary.

The version I'm uploading has 3 holes as it matches the use I was going to give it but I can alter the design if needed.
It still has the normal center hole for the M6 screw found in cameras.

Transport case for Medtronic insulin pump canister/ reservoir.
the 3D file has break off parts to make sure it does not get pushed off the hot bed. both parts are printed in PLA with 0.2mm thickness on a printrbot plus.
If you have a different type pump I will on request upload the inventor files so you can modify length and width to suit your brand. PS. you have to flip the object 90 degrees so it lays down.
(inventor problem)

I have found that if you print parts that has a tendency to lift in the corners or even loose their grip and fall off it pays off to make a break off skirt around the part (see pics) the first attempt on this part did not have a wide enough skirt so it was pushed off by the extruder

title: Laterne - laterna with LED for Christmas

description.text:
Laterne fuer den Weihnachtsbaum.
laterna for Christmas tree. Just drill a hole with about 6mm in the middle on the top of laterna put a Standard LED into and connect a 100 ohm resistor to a small Lithium battery. The both wires are to Close the circuit-contact and to hang it on tree. To get the LED off, just open the both wires or put them together on the isulation. That's all
Enjoy your Christmas !

I draw it in Google sketchup (3D), then i exported the file to .3ds Format, converted again with free converter to .stl-format in order to get it on my 3D-printer Duplicator 4. Then let my 3D-printer run and build it with 100% full material, bottom and external Support, used 1.75mm Filament red transparent, working-speed: 80, free-speed: 120, after finishing i did the brake-away of the external Support materials around by Hand with Little Tools and - voila... got is.
Afer raw-production i drilled a 6mm hole into middle of top put in a 6mm spacer ring, within i put a Standard LED, bende the both wires on top of laterna, welded a 100 ohm resistor, welded some small cables to a Lithium 3,5V battery. Isulated all with duck-tape and put These both wires through the small holes of the top-holder. When contacting both wires, laterna will light, open then it is off. Just simple and a nice Thing for our Christmas tree.

title: 1969 Mustang  simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After several simplified planes-models I decided it'd be time for a car. Inspired by Jake Diaz I went with a classic muscle car: the 1969 Ford Mustang. Other than Jake I used plywood only. To make the back wheels stick out a little further I used two washers on each side.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. I used baltic birch plywood and an unknown red wood as well as beech plywood for the second version. A 6 mm beech rod made the axles. I added a little bit of grease to improve the rotation.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen for more toy designs.

print_settings.Notes:: The spool cylinder was 0,8mm side shell, 0,9mm top/bottom shell and 10% infill.

description.text: Spool holder that goes between LCD and frame instead of white spacers.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I made 2% oversize to accommodate ABS shrinkage, but it came out little to big and fit quite tight on the screws, so I think there is no need for that.
I also used brims for print. The print was wade on kapton tape with ABS, The print peeled of the tape of the bed little bit just at the end of the print, but it came out really nice.
I would also recommend to turn off combing (in cura: Expert config - Retraction - Enable combing). With combing it pushes of the filament out of extruder on the path to the holes and the holes are printed pretty bad.

The spool cylinder was 0,8mm side shell, 0,9mm top/bottom shell and 10% infill.

author: plastkort

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ahs1l5TAwX0
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gx4YAXuRlRC

This is a models library for most of the existing ESP8266 based modules.
I use these while designing project cases, so I hope it will be helpful for someone.

As some of the devices were drawn from pictures, there could still be some dimensional errors...

The file "ESP8266Models.scad" is meant to be used as a library (using "use <ESP8266Models.scad">"), as illustrated in the "test.scad" file. If it's opened by itself, all modules will be displayed.

Comments and corrections are welcome.

Update V1.1 on 2017-02-23 :

  • Added holes location functions for USB connectors and push buttons (see test.scad for usage information)

comments.text: This is super useful! thank you so much.
comments.author: TinkeringTanuki

comments.text: No esp 13, right?
comments.author: vadimbz

comments.text:
Hi. Not for now. I've already made a promise to include variations of the NodeMCU board, and this should have been uploaded a week ago, but I don't have enough free time to finish the work.
I'll try to do it next week, so don't loose hope...
comments.author: vadimbz

comments.text:
Well, esp13 could clearly use it. In case you haven't seen it, pinou-wise it's similar to esp 12, but the edges are shaved like on esp 06,
and what a ruthless shaving it was, i.e. pin contacts ended up as half-circular recesses for 0.5 jumper.
Which effectively excludes most if not all potentially compatible breadboards.
comments.author: DonJuanito

comments.text: Nice work. I use the ESP12F module to design a next model ESP-programmer. To make the use of pins clear I addes the pin descriptions.  I am new to Open SCAD, so the code could more efficient perhaps to use in other modules to.

title: BCN3D Sigma External Bondtec Extruder Mounts

description.text: Mounts for external Bondtech extruders as supplied here https://emvioeng.com/shop/bcn3d-technology-products/bondtech-kit-for-bcn3d-sigma/

comments.text: Creator: were you able to position the motors by re-routing the stepper motor cables, or was it necessary to purchase/create new cables to reach? If you purchased new cables, can you post the source?
comments.author: freddotu

comments.text: External mounting will require new cables. I'm pretty sure iDevelo3D will have made his own up at the time.  when i bought my bondtechs from emvioeng.com they were able to provide me with cables as well.  Might be worth contacting them and see what they can supply. they do also sell a complete kit.
comments.author: freddotu

comments.text: I had had some problems with the connectors coming apart, discovered during my Bondtech installation. I was able to purchase connector housing and pins to match the existing ones. I have sufficient remaining to construct my own cables, as well as the crimping tool. Would you please to give me an approximate length of the cables to permit me to order the necessary wiring?
comments.author: chimpusmaximus

comments.text: I'm really wondering if this is better or the same as the external kit emvio is selling. I just ordered the bondtechs and want to place them outside.
comments.author: photoholic

comments.text: These mounts were the initial starting point I believe for the ones that Emvio now provide. To mount these securely you have to drill through the main frame of the Sigma (twice of each side). I'm not sure if this is the case for the Emvio ones but i suspect not.
comments.author: photoholic

comments.text: okay thanks a lot for your answers... emio's can do it without holes ;)
comments.author: chimpusmaximus

comments.text: Can you tell if this is for the Sigma R17 and which screws are nedded? Thanks a lot

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: For a few weeks now I have been trying to get a design flying. This is the closest I've gotten so far. It does fly, you need to through it pretty hard and straight; it may make a fun toy to play with even if you can't make it fly. I made 3 main gliders; a short with 100% infill, a long with 100% infill, and a long with 10% infill. I've been having fun trying to get them to fly and I'm currently working on a launcher.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

high

Infill:

printed at 10% and 100%

Notes:

Takes 2-3 hours maybe a bit more to print. On my Robo 3D I needed to tilt the long glider roughly 45 degrees to get the best print I could.

It is hard to throw and takes some power, but I have gotten it to fly a little. You may want to consider throwing it out side. My cat loves to chase it and swat it out of the sky as well but don't try to throw it at people or pets because it might hurt (still didn't stop my cat from chasing it after I threw it, I think she enjoys it).

I hold it like this when I throw it back view of throw grip failed designs

remixed_from.author: tshilling
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Plus, V2, CNC Router, 1/16in endmill

title: Printrbot Plus Base Aluminium Plate (Extended X/Y)

description.text:
1/4in thick Aluminium plate to replace wood base of Printrbot plus. Acrylic legs. Extends X-Axis by 1in and X by 1/2in. Easier access to electronics. Note:
To stabilize X axis rods, ~0.1in shim required between x-axis rods and Z axis bearings (See picture). This clamps the rods really well and I get better stability than previously non-extended version. An alternative would be to buy new rods, but who wants to do that? Also, please realize that the electronic mounting holes are for ramps. You will also need a 90deg USB-B type connector or use ~1in standoffs to clear the y axis bearing block.

comments.text: Commenting on myself here.  I built this out of aluminium and was initially impressed however the mess of wires and the lack of stability in the X direction caused me to revert to a wood structure similiar to the original.  The design is fine, but if you build it, you will want to add some stability to the legs.

title: DJI Osmo 4K stabilised camera - iPad Mini mounting brackets

description.text:
I was getting fed up of my Osmo chewing through my phone battery leaving me with no communication on shoots. Therefore, I decided to design these mounting brackets so I could make use of the longer lasting iPad battery and get a better screen in the process. The iPad doesn't weigh the camera down too much.

These brackets have slots for the existing phone mounts to click into, then the spring-loaded arm can extend to allow the brackets to clip around the corners of the iPad Mini. As long as your spring isn't worn, your iPad will be locked in place nice and tight.

I've printed this in just about every material you can think of, including PolyFlex, PolyWood, PolyMax, CF Bronzefill and many different PLAs, but found ProtoPasta Matte Fiber HTPLA my favorite for finish, weight and strength. PolyWood comes out awesome if you sand it and a combo of any colour with a layer of Matte Fiber on top looks wicked if you can remember to swap the filament on the layer where the DJI logo sides start to print.

In the end I kinda stuck with 0.2mm, 3 shells, 3 top and 3 bottom layers, 30% infill and printed with DJI logo facing up with supports enabled. This way the iPad covers any rough spots from the support and it allows you to do the two-tone thing with the logo (see pics)

title: AARP "Dynamic A" Whistle v4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[With lanyard lug added, and set to recommended print size. See "AARP Whistle v1" if you don't want the lug. v5 of the whistle has an improved airway http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1948913]

The first AARP "Dynamic A" logo whistle is working! Thanks to my pal Doug Duarte in ITS for the long term loan of the MakerBot Mini to the innovation lab and for suggesting that the logo be made into a whistle. I created the logo outline and the shape of the interior air cavity in the non-cloud version of Adobe Illustrator. Then I imported both SVG vectors into TinkerCAD and set the air cavity shape as a "hole." The resulting model was sent to the Thingiverse site and then downloaded into the MakerBot software on my laptop for printing. This red one with lug took 40 minutes at standard settings with dimensions set at X: 50.75 mm, Y: 36.10 mm, Z: 8.00 mm, medium resolution. Turning off infill would have saved 3 minutes, so I didn't bother.

Video of the functioning whistle:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BNabMclBu14/

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iAMFkIV7VWz

title: Flexion for E3D Retrofit kit for E3D Hotend for Smartrapcore
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Flexion for E3D Retrofit kit bracket for the Smartrapcore series of RepRap printers. This bracket mounts in the same place the normal hotend bracket would be attached with the 4 screws. It holds the Flexion E3D Retrofit kit along with the NEMA17 motor. The Flexion E3D Retrofit kit then holds the E3D V6 or E3D lite6 hotends.

The bracket holds the mounting block of the Flexion Extruder up to allow the motor to be out of the way and does not interfere with any movement or homing. It clears the X motor during a home, and is held away from the belts as to not interfere with normal travel.

I have it fit on my Smartrapcore ALU, but it should fit the Smartrapcore and Smartrapcore 300XL since they all use the same head block.

There is also a version for the E3D V6 (Volcano) that brings the extruder up for the increased length of the Volcano heatblock.

Designed in Onshape

author: PDBeal

description.text:
Christmas tree with a snowflake. The snowflake is gimbaled to spin on a vertical axis. The design can be printed in two pieces and snapped together, or in a single print either in one color or with dual extrusion.  
I designed this ornament to drop in the envelope with our Christmas cards this year, so it's small enough and thin enough to fit in an envelope.

There are three STL files: one with the tree and the snowflake as an assembled unit, and one for each part as separate parts. All parts are designed to print without support.  
The STL for the assembled ornament can be used if you want to print the whole thing at once in a single color.  
The STL files for the separate parts should work for dualstrusion, but I haven't tested this.  
The photo shows the tree printed in dark green and the snowflake in transparent. These were printed separately and snapped together.

author: Jellono

description.text: BB-8…if you don’t know is the cute little round droid who featured in the Star Wars movie released in December last year (2015), The Force Awakens. BB-8, as luck would have it, is a really simple design that could be mistaken for a bauble, so, we thought, why not turn him into a Xmas tree decoration! So fire up your 3D printer, grab some fancy festive looking paint buy some glitter and see what you can come up with.
Clean up scaffolding carefully please!

print_settings.Notes:: I used the brim settings to prevent warping on my printbed.

description.text:
The idea behind this thing is to highlight something you have achieved, so once in a while you stop by and remember what you got. You can also use it to show off, but that's not the point.

The glass figure is actually a trophy, a little reward by our town when you have achieved some sort of upper educational level.

Partlist
  • 3 high intensity 5mm LEDs, white
  • 3 resistors, 150 Ohms/0.25W
  • 1 Micro USB B female PCB connector
  • wires
  • some hot glue

The holes for the LEDs are 6mm wide on the upper side of the platform and 8mm wide on the bottom, so the leads and plastic enclosing of the LED fit perfectly. The micro USB connector is a bit tricky to install, but you can use small pliers and carefully push it into place. It is even possible to solder the connector to the wires after installation.

PVC thread:
May need to clean threads. I used oil when cleaning threads with 10 mm die.
1.25 pitch is fine as 1.50 pitch is course.

Hex head coupling:
Sized for a structural grade bolt head. Standard grade bolt head may be smaller. Glue or use silicone to secure if necessary.

May need to clean the inside ridge of coupling for better fit-up.

Different colors of filament will give different finish dimensions using the same stl file.
Slower speed on the threads produced better results for me.

print_settings.Notes:: The model has a tendency to pop off the bed when printing. So use the hairspray or tape and keep the bed hot! Taping it down after the base circle prints would be smart.

description.text:
The 4 inch model is meant to display the conic sections in mathematics on a 3D scale. The conic sections come from 2 cones, stacked on top of each other (tip to tip), being cut by planes in a 3D space, and the resulting cuts create 2D graphs. With the help of this model, the origin of these conic shapes can be seen more clearly and manipulated by mathematicians and students. Those who use the model can see the different types of shapes that are created as well as how they relate to each other in the cones they were created from.

The use of conic sections in the classroom is one of the Maine mathematics standards as dictated by the Common Core Mathematics Standards. Standards CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GPE.A.1, 2, and 3; all discuss the idea of conic sections graphically as well as through equations. Yet the conceptual ideas of the conic sections and where they come from is not as easy to understand. Even if students are given a set of equations and how to work with them, it doesn’t help the students see how it relates to cones. By having this model in the classroom, students can see where the planes cut the cone to make the different 2D shapes from a 3D model.

(A. Reynolds - MAT 363, December 2014)

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The model has a tendency to pop off the bed when printing. So use the hairspray or tape and keep the bed hot! Taping it down after the base circle prints would be smart.

The design process of this model began by using Rhinoceros, or Rhino. Two cones were constructed so that the tops, or the tipped points, were intersected at the point of the top. Then, planes cut through the model at certain angles to create the 2D graphical representations. The parabola was cut so that it hit only 1 cone from a slanted vertical angle. The hyperbola was cut so that the plane hit both cones at a slanted vertical angle. The ellipse was made by cutting one cone at a slanted horizontal angle. The circle and the point were created by the construction of the two cones together, where you can slice one cone at a straight, horizontal line across to get the circle and the point is the intersection of the two cones. The last conic section, the line, was the first problem in the design process. The lines were made by creating a skeleton of the 2 cones and removing the Rhino designed cones.
Once the ellipse, the hyperbola, and the parabola were created, the intersection of the plane and the cones were made in Rhino. The planes were then removed, leaving only the curves created by the slicing planes. Then, the cones themselves were deleted from the model, leaving only “floating” curves that were created.
We then constructed 4 lines from the two circles left from the cones, creating a skeleton of a cone. The model then had all of the components required of the conic sections and was theoretically printable.
The model was then piped to create thickness in the model so that it could be 3D printed.

(AR, Dec. 2014)

Mathematical Questions/Challenges

When the model was failing to print, we realized that the printer was attempting to print on a point of singularity. The middle point, technically, is a single point on the entire plane. Even though the model added width with the piping, there still was such a small surface area that the printer was struggling to build up from it. The problem that was discovered was that in order for the model to be printable, there were two issues to consider. The first issue was how big to get the intersection so that it was strong enough to support the top half of the cones. When we increased the pipe width, the surface area increased, which should solve the problem of the thinness in the model.
Yet when we increased the piping in order to increase the surface area, the weight from the top half of the model also increased. This created the problem that the weight was still too large, even for the increased surface area. As we attempted to increase the surface area, the weight increased. The pressure from the top half of the cone was too great for the smaller surface area to support. We then considered how to increase the surface area on the intersection between the two cones without increasing the weight as well.
The angle between the two cones also affected the surface area as well. As the angle increased, the surface area on the point also increased because the cross sections of the intersection became wider. This should have, in theory, not increased the weight too much in order to balance out the weight and pressure problem. Yet when it was attempting to print, the model was still considered to be too thin in multiple areas. We realized that Rhino will pipe items by doing a multiple radius pipe. This method tapers the pipe so that it is smaller on one end.
The idea to do a multiple radius piping helped also to decrease the weight on the top of the model. Hopefully, all of these new variables will help make the next print a little bit larger. The size of the last print is a good individual size, but if we wanted a larger model to print with there will have to be more mathematics done.

(AR, Dec. 2014)

print_settings.Notes::
I printed this model at 290.34% on an Ultimaker 3, using dual material and soluble support structures. The model printed incredibly well at a layer height of 0.1 mm and 15% infill. I slowed the printing speed down to 45 mm/s to better reproduce some of the smaller features.

 Along with the STL file of the entire model, I've included a file for just the top and bottom, which may print better when not using soluble support structures. Print these files using the same settings as the previous model.

description.text:
"In order to prevent war, the Galaxy is on Orion's Belt"

 This model is a replica of the galaxy prop that hung from the neck of Gentle Rosenberg's cat, Orion, in the original Men in Black movie. Gentle Rosenberg was the prince of the Arquillians and died early in the movie, leaving behind his cat and the Galaxy of his people.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: 
 I printed this model at 290.34% on an Ultimaker 3, using dual material and soluble support structures. The model printed incredibly well at a layer height of 0.1 mm and 15% infill. I slowed the printing speed down to 45 mm/s to better reproduce some of the smaller features.

 Along with the STL file of the entire model, I've included a file for just the top and bottom, which may print better when not using soluble support structures. Print these files using the same settings as the previous model.

I lightly sanded the model and then painted it using a mix of gold and silver Testors enamel paint. I also placed a small Christmas ornament inside the model to reproduce the galaxy orb in the movie; however, I've included a printable orb if you'd prefer to print this piece too.

comments.text:
That is neat! Thank you for that :)
I suppose you could make one smaller and use a marble too.
comments.author: sporak

comments.text: Any smaller and it becomes difficult to print because of resolution limitations. Perhaps a DLP or SLA printer could print it smaller, but as for FDM printing goes, this is almost as small as it gets.
comments.author: sporak

title: Power button for "Spidem Villa" coffee machine

description.text: This is a replacement part for a Spidem Villa coffee machine. The power button of our machine broke, so I designed this one to replace it. Please note that this is no forge of an original drawing whatsoever. I just measured and tried various things.

Printer:

German RepRap Neo

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

100%

comments.text: Great, just what I was looking for, because my old power button had a crack in the inner tube that sits on the switch. So it only sat loosely or could fall off. The advantage of THIS design is that the button can not fall off any more.
